contents: The next day we landed at Sidon, and Julius treated Paul with consideration, allowing him to visit his friends and receive their care.

contents.verseText: After putting out from there, we sailed to the lee of Cyprus because the winds were against us.
contents: After putting out from there, we sailed to the lee of Cyprus because the winds were against us.

contents.verseText: And when we had sailed across the open sea off the coast of Cilicia and Pamphylia, we came to Myra in Lycia.
contents: And when we had sailed across the open sea off the coast of Cilicia and Pamphylia, we came to Myra in Lycia.

contents.verseText: There the centurion found an Alexandrian ship sailing for Italy and put us on board.
contents: There the centurion found an Alexandrian ship sailing for Italy and put us on board.

contents.verseText: After sailing slowly for many days, we arrived off Cnidus. When the wind impeded us, we sailed to the lee of Crete, opposite Salmone.
contents: After sailing slowly for many days, we arrived off Cnidus. When the wind impeded us, we sailed to the lee of Crete, opposite Salmone.

contents.verseText: After we had moved along the coast with difficulty, we came to a place called Fair Havens, near the town of Lasea.
contents: After we had moved along the coast with difficulty, we came to a place called Fair Havens, near the town of Lasea.

contents.verseText: By now much time had passed, and the voyage had already become dangerous because it was after the Fast. So Paul advised them,
contents: By now much time had passed, and the voyage had already become dangerous because it was after the Fast.

footnote.ft: That is, Yom Kippur, the Day of Atonement

contents: So Paul advised them,

contents.verseText: “Men, I can see that our voyage will be filled with disaster and great loss, not only to ship and cargo, but to our own lives as well.”
contents: “Men, I can see that our voyage will be filled with disaster and great loss, not only to ship and cargo, but to our own lives as well.”

contents.verseText: But contrary to Paul’s advice, the centurion was persuaded by the pilot and by the owner of the ship.
contents: But contrary to Paul’s advice, the centurion was persuaded by the pilot and by the owner of the ship.

contents.verseText: Since the harbor was unsuitable to winter in, the majority decided to sail on, if somehow they could reach Phoenix to winter there. Phoenix was a harbor in Crete facing both southwest and northwest.
contents: Since the harbor was unsuitable to winter in, the majority decided to sail on, if somehow they could reach Phoenix to winter there. Phoenix was a harbor in Crete facing both southwest and northwest.

contents.verseText: When a gentle south wind began to blow, they thought they had their opportunity. So they weighed anchor and sailed along, hugging the coast of Crete.
contents: When a gentle south wind began to blow, they thought they had their opportunity. So they weighed anchor and sailed along, hugging the coast of Crete.

contents.verseText: But it was not long before a cyclone called the Northeaster swept down across the island.
contents: But it was not long before a cyclone called the Northeaster swept down across the island.

contents.verseText: Unable to head into the wind, the ship was caught up. So we gave way and let ourselves be driven along.
contents: Unable to head into the wind, the ship was caught up. So we gave way and let ourselves be driven along.

contents.verseText: Passing to the lee of a small island called Cauda, we barely managed to secure the lifeboat.
contents: Passing to the lee of a small island called Cauda,

footnote.ft: NE, BYZ, and TR Clauda

contents: we barely managed to secure the lifeboat.

contents.verseText: After hoisting it up, the crew used ropes to undergird the ship. And fearing that they would run aground on the sandbars of Syrtis, they lowered the sea anchor and were driven along.
contents: After hoisting it up, the crew used ropes to undergird the ship. And fearing that they would run aground on the sandbars of Syrtis, they lowered the sea anchor

footnote.ft: Or the sails

contents: and were driven along.

contents.verseText: We were tossed so violently that the next day the men began to jettison the cargo.
contents: We were tossed so violently that the next day the men began to jettison the cargo.

contents.verseText: On the third day, they threw the ship’s tackle overboard with their own hands.
contents: On the third day, they threw the ship’s tackle overboard with their own hands.

contents.verseText: When neither sun nor stars appeared for many days and the great storm continued to batter us, we abandoned all hope of being saved.
contents: When neither sun nor stars appeared for many days and the great storm continued to batter us, we abandoned all hope of being saved.

contents.verseText: After the men had gone a long time without food, Paul stood up among them and said, “Men, you should have followed my advice not to sail from Crete. Then you would have averted this disaster and loss.
contents: After the men had gone a long time without food, Paul stood up among them and said, “Men, you should have followed my advice not to sail from Crete. Then you would have averted this disaster and loss.

contents.verseText: But now I urge you to keep up your courage, because you will not experience any loss of life, but only of the ship.
contents: But now I urge you to keep up your courage, because you will not experience any loss of life, but only of the ship.

contents.verseText: For just last night an angel of God, whose I am and whom I serve, stood beside me
contents: For just last night an angel of God, whose I am and whom I serve, stood beside me

contents.verseText: and said, ‘Do not be afraid, Paul; you must stand before Caesar. And look, God has granted you the lives of all who sail with you.’
contents: and said, ‘Do not be afraid, Paul; you must stand before Caesar. And look, God has granted you the lives of all who sail with you.’

contents.verseText: So take courage, men, for I believe God that it will happen just as He told me.
contents: So take courage, men, for I believe God that it will happen just as He told me.

contents.verseText: However, we must run aground on some island.”
contents: However, we must run aground on some island.”

contents.verseText: On the fourteenth night we were still being driven across the Adriatic Sea. About midnight the sailors sensed they were approaching land.
contents: On the fourteenth night we were still being driven across the Adriatic Sea.

footnote.ft: The Adriatic Sea referred to an area extending well south of Italy to include the central portion of the Mediterranean Sea.

contents: About midnight the sailors sensed they were approaching land.

contents.verseText: They took soundings and found that the water was twenty fathoms deep. Going a little farther, they took another set of soundings that read fifteen fathoms.
contents: They took soundings and found that the water was twenty fathoms deep.

footnote.ft: 20 fathoms is approximately 120 feet or 36.6 meters.

contents: Going a little farther, they took another set of soundings that read fifteen fathoms.

footnote.ft: 15 fathoms is approximately 90 feet or 27.4 meters.

contents.verseText: Fearing that we would run aground on the rocks, they dropped four anchors from the stern and prayed for daybreak.
contents: Fearing that we would run aground on the rocks, they dropped four anchors from the stern and prayed for daybreak.

contents.verseText: Meanwhile, the sailors attempted to escape from the ship. Pretending to lower anchors from the bow, they let the lifeboat down into the sea.
contents: Meanwhile, the sailors attempted to escape from the ship. Pretending to lower anchors from the bow, they let the lifeboat down into the sea.

contents.verseText: But Paul said to the centurion and the soldiers, “Unless these men remain with the ship, you cannot be saved.”
contents: But Paul said to the centurion and the soldiers, “Unless these men remain with the ship, you cannot be saved.”

contents.verseText: So the soldiers cut the ropes to the lifeboat and set it adrift.
contents: So the soldiers cut the ropes to the lifeboat and set it adrift.

contents.verseText: Right up to daybreak, Paul kept urging them all to eat: “Today is your fourteenth day in constant suspense, without taking any food.
contents: Right up to daybreak, Paul kept urging them all to eat: “Today is your fourteenth day in constant suspense, without taking any food.

contents.verseText: So for your own preservation, I urge you to eat something, because not a single hair of your head will be lost.”
contents: So for your own preservation, I urge you to eat something, because not a single hair of your head will be lost.”

contents.verseText: After he had said this, Paul took bread and gave thanks to God in front of them all. Then he broke it and began to eat.
contents: After he had said this, Paul took bread and gave thanks to God in front of them all. Then he broke it and began to eat.

contents.verseText: They were all encouraged and took some food themselves.
contents: They were all encouraged and took some food themselves.

contents.verseText: In all, there were 276 of us on board.
contents: In all, there were 276

footnote.ft: WH 76

contents: of us on board.

contents.verseText: After the men had eaten their fill, they lightened the ship by throwing the grain into the sea.
contents: After the men had eaten their fill, they lightened the ship by throwing the grain into the sea.

contents.verseText: When daylight came, they did not recognize the land, but they sighted a bay with a sandy beach, where they decided to run the ship aground if they could.
contents: When daylight came, they did not recognize the land, but they sighted a bay with a sandy beach, where they decided to run the ship aground if they could.

contents.verseText: Cutting away the anchors, they left them in the sea as they loosened the ropes that held the rudders. Then they hoisted the foresail to the wind and made for the beach.
contents: Cutting away the anchors, they left them in the sea as they loosened the ropes that held the rudders. Then they hoisted the foresail to the wind and made for the beach.

contents.verseText: But the vessel struck a sandbar and ran aground. The bow stuck fast and would not move, and the stern was being broken up by the pounding of the waves.
contents: But the vessel struck a sandbar and ran aground. The bow stuck fast and would not move, and the stern was being broken up by the pounding of the waves.

contents.verseText: The soldiers planned to kill the prisoners so none of them could swim to freedom.
contents: The soldiers planned to kill the prisoners so none of them could swim to freedom.

contents.verseText: But the centurion, wanting to spare Paul’s life, thwarted their plan. He commanded those who could swim to jump overboard first and get to land.
contents: But the centurion, wanting to spare Paul’s life, thwarted their plan. He commanded those who could swim to jump overboard first and get to land.

contents.verseText: The rest were to follow on planks and various parts of the ship. In this way everyone was brought safely to land.
contents: The rest were to follow on planks and various parts of the ship. In this way everyone was brought safely to land.

contents.verseText: Once we were safely ashore, we learned that the island was called Malta.
contents: Once we were safely ashore, we learned that the island was called Malta.

contents.verseText: The islanders showed us extraordinary kindness. They kindled a fire and welcomed all of us because it was raining and cold.
contents: The islanders showed us extraordinary kindness. They kindled a fire and welcomed all of us because it was raining and cold.

contents.verseText: Paul gathered a bundle of sticks, and as he laid them on the fire, a viper, driven out by the heat, fastened itself to his hand.
contents: Paul gathered a bundle of sticks, and as he laid them on the fire, a viper, driven out by the heat, fastened itself to his hand.

contents.verseText: When the islanders saw the creature hanging from his hand, they said to one another, “Surely this man is a murderer. Although he was saved from the sea, Justice has not allowed him to live.”
contents: When the islanders saw the creature hanging from his hand, they said to one another, “Surely this man is a murderer. Although he was saved from the sea, Justice

footnote.ft: Greek Dike; that is, the Greek goddess of justice

contents: has not allowed him to live.”

contents.verseText: But Paul shook the creature off into the fire and suffered no ill effects.
contents: But Paul shook the creature off into the fire and suffered no ill effects.

contents.verseText: The islanders were expecting him to swell up or suddenly drop dead. But after waiting a long time and seeing nothing unusual happen to him, they changed their minds and said he was a god.
contents: The islanders were expecting him to swell up or suddenly drop dead. But after waiting a long time and seeing nothing unusual happen to him, they changed their minds and said he was a god.

contents.verseText: Nearby stood an estate belonging to Publius, the chief official of the island. He welcomed us and entertained us hospitably for three days.
contents: Nearby stood an estate belonging to Publius, the chief official of the island. He welcomed us and entertained us hospitably for three days.

contents.verseText: The father of Publius was sick in bed, suffering from fever and dysentery. Paul went in to see him, and after praying and placing his hands on him, he healed the man.
contents: The father of Publius was sick in bed, suffering from fever and dysentery. Paul went in to see him, and after praying and placing his hands on him, he healed the man.

contents.verseText: After this had happened, the rest of the sick on the island came and were cured as well.
contents: After this had happened, the rest of the sick on the island came and were cured as well.

contents.verseText: The islanders honored us in many ways and supplied our needs when we were ready to sail.
contents: The islanders honored us in many ways and supplied our needs when we were ready to sail.

contents.verseText: After three months we set sail in an Alexandrian ship that had wintered in the island. It had the Twin Brothers as a figurehead.
contents: After three months we set sail in an Alexandrian ship that had wintered in the island. It had the Twin Brothers

footnote.ft: Greek Dioscuri; that is, the Greek gods Castor and Pollux

contents: as a figurehead.

contents.verseText: Putting in at Syracuse, we stayed there three days.
contents: Putting in at Syracuse, we stayed there three days.

contents.verseText: From there we weighed anchor and came to Rhegium. After one day, a south wind came up, and on the second day we arrived at Puteoli.
contents: From there we weighed anchor and came to Rhegium. After one day, a south wind came up, and on the second day we arrived at Puteoli.

contents.verseText: There we found some brothers who invited us to spend the week with them. And so we came to Rome.
contents: There we found some brothers who invited us to spend the week with them. And so we came to Rome.

contents.verseText: The brothers there had heard about us and traveled as far as the Forum of Appius and the Three Taverns to meet us. When Paul saw them, he was encouraged and gave thanks to God.
contents: The brothers there had heard about us and traveled as far as the Forum of Appius

footnote.ft: The Forum of Appius was about 43 miles or 70 kilometers from Rome.

contents: and the Three Taverns

footnote.ft: The Three Taverns was about 35 miles or 57 kilometers from Rome.

contents: to meet us. When Paul saw them, he was encouraged and gave thanks to God.

contents.verseText: When we arrived in Rome, Paul was permitted to stay by himself, with a soldier to guard him.
contents: When we arrived in Rome,

footnote.ft: BYZ and TR include the centurion delivered up the prisoners to the captain of the barrack, but.

contents: Paul was permitted to stay by himself, with a soldier to guard him.

contents.verseText: After three days, he called together the leaders of the Jews. When they had gathered, he said to them, “Brothers, although I have done nothing against our people or the customs of our fathers, I was taken prisoner in Jerusalem and handed over to the Romans.
contents: After three days, he called together the leaders of the Jews. When they had gathered, he said to them, “Brothers, although I have done nothing against our people or the customs of our fathers, I was taken prisoner in Jerusalem and handed over to the Romans.

contents.verseText: They examined me and wanted to release me, because there was no basis for a death sentence against me.
contents: They examined me and wanted to release me, because there was no basis for a death sentence against me.

contents.verseText: But when the Jews objected, I was compelled to appeal to Caesar, even though I have no charge to bring against my nation.
contents: But when the Jews objected, I was compelled to appeal to Caesar, even though I have no charge to bring against my nation.

contents.verseText: So for this reason I have called to see you and speak with you. It is because of the hope of Israel that I am bound with this chain.”
contents: So for this reason I have called to see you and speak with you. It is because of the hope of Israel that I am bound with this chain.”

contents.verseText: The leaders replied, “We have not received any letters about you from Judea, nor have any of the brothers from there reported or even mentioned anything bad about you.
contents: The leaders replied, “We have not received any letters about you from Judea, nor have any of the brothers from there reported or even mentioned anything bad about you.

contents.verseText: But we consider your views worth hearing, because we know that people everywhere are speaking against this sect.”
contents: But we consider your views worth hearing, because we know that people everywhere are speaking against this sect.”

contents.verseText: So they set a day to meet with Paul, and many people came to the place he was staying. He expounded to them from morning to evening, testifying about the kingdom of God and persuading them about Jesus from the Law of Moses and the Prophets.
contents: So they set a day to meet with Paul, and many people came to the place he was staying. He expounded to them from morning to evening, testifying about the kingdom of God and persuading them about Jesus from the Law of Moses and the Prophets.

contents.verseText: Some of them were convinced by what he said, but others refused to believe.
contents: Some of them were convinced by what he said, but others refused to believe.

contents.verseText: They disagreed among themselves and began to leave after Paul had made this final statement: “The Holy Spirit was right when He spoke to your fathers through Isaiah the prophet:
contents: They disagreed among themselves and began to leave after Paul had made this final statement: “The Holy Spirit was right when He spoke to your fathers through Isaiah the prophet:

contents.verseText: ‘Go to this people and say, “You will be ever hearing but never understanding; you will be ever seeing but never perceiving.”
contents: ‘Go to this people and say,
“You will be ever hearing but never understanding;
you will be ever seeing but never perceiving.”

contents.verseText: For this people’s heart has grown callous; they hardly hear with their ears, and they have closed their eyes. Otherwise they might see with their eyes, hear with their ears, understand with their hearts, and turn, and I would heal them.’
contents: For this people’s heart has grown callous;
they hardly hear with their ears,
and they have closed their eyes.
Otherwise they might see with their eyes,
hear with their ears,
understand with their hearts,
and turn, and I would heal them.’

footnote.ft: Isaiah 6:9–10 (see also LXX)

contents.verseText: Be advised, therefore, that God’s salvation has been sent to the Gentiles, and they will listen!”
contents: Be advised, therefore, that God’s salvation has been sent to the Gentiles, and they will listen!”

footnote.ft: BYZ and TR include 29 When he had said this, the Jews went away, disputing sharply among themselves.

contents.verseText: Paul stayed there two full years in his own rented house, welcoming all who came to visit him.
contents: Paul stayed there two full years in his own rented house, welcoming all who came to visit him.

contents.verseText: Boldly and freely he proclaimed the kingdom of God and taught about the Lord Jesus Christ.
contents: Boldly and freely he proclaimed the kingdom of God and taught about the Lord Jesus Christ.
